children.value: partial equilibrium model with heterogeneous consumers
Empirically calibrated to match observed consumption patterns
Captures selection effects from price controls
, who document that approximately 40% of stadium attendees consume alcohol, we model two distinct consumer types. Non-drinkers comprise 60% of attendees and have low beer preference (

children.html: αbeer=1.0\alpha_{beer} = 1.0αbeer​=1.0

children.value: ) but high value for the stadium experience (

children.html: αexperience=3.0\alpha_{experience} = 3.0αexperience​=3.0

children.value: ). These fans attend for the game itself and consume zero beers at typical prices. Drinkers comprise the remaining 40% with substantially higher beer preference (

children.html: αbeer=43.75\alpha_{beer} = 43.75αbeer​=43.75

children.value: ) calibrated to match observed consumption of 2.5 beers at \
12.50. Their stadium experience value is moderate (
children.html: 12.50.Theirstadiumexperiencevalueismoderate(12.50. Their stadium experience value is moderate (12.50.Theirstadiumexperiencevalueismoderate(

children.value: \alpha_{experience} = 2.5$) as beer consumption forms an integral part of their game-day experience.
This heterogeneous specification improves model calibration by 76% compared to a representative consumer approach, reducing prediction error for optimal beer prices from \

children.html: 2.09to2.09 to \\2.09to

children.value: 0.50. More importantly, it captures selection effects absent from homogeneous models: price policies change not only how many fans attend, but which types of fans attend.
